utterances: Is that reason to take advantage of them?

Joining us now from her office in Bentonville, Arkansas, is Mona Williams, vice president for corporate communications at Wal-Mart.
And thanks very much for being with us today.
Oh, thank you, Neal.
I think I'm going to need four or five hours, though, to refute a lot of the things that have been said over the last few minutes.
Well, I'm assuming Linda's conversation was not one of them.
But let me ask you a broad question first.
Why has Wal-Mart decided now is the time to--well, people are calling it a public-relations campaign--but to publicize a lot of the things that it's been doing?

I think you make a key point there, and it's important that folks understand that our activities over the past weeks and months are really not just about communicating outward and making it a PR campaign, but it's really an attempt to make sure we're thinking about the right things and make sure that people in the country are thinking about the right things.

It's a little bit of a shift for us, because as we continue to mature as a company, we're thinking about our business in a new way, and key to that is that a lot of the issues, Neal, that we've dealt with from a defense posture, some of the wages, the benefits, the ethical sourcing, the environment--we're trying to look at those as opportunities to embrace proactively and become a stronger company along the way.
So, clearly, there's more work to do there, but what Lee Scott tried to do last week was lay out a framework for our thinking and do just that.
Mm-hmm.
Who is responsible, if Wal-Mart has--to the extent that Wal-Mart has a bad image, who is responsible for that?
Well, I think there are probably multiple folks who can step up to that.

You know, we have different types of critics, and I think it's important that we understand there are some folks who aren't going to like us no matter what we do, people who want, you know, us to fail because it lifts them up, and those are some of our competitors and, clearly, the labor unions.

But to be fair, we've made a lot of our own mistakes, so we try to turn toward the other group of critics, and these are people with genuine concerns in these areas who want to work with us and help us to become better in the process and make the country a better place, and we're spending a lot of time with those folks, having a lot of thoughtful discussions.
And including this conference here in Washington, DC, where you've asked academics to write papers.
You don't know what the results are going to be or even if they're going to be positive for Wal-Mart.
No, and there's a lot of risk for us there.

And there have been a lot of studies, some, you know, reasonably valid, some a little bit dubious, over the past few years, and in the defense of folks writing these, they really did not have all of the Wal-Mart data.
And so our primary reason for having the conference this Friday is really to make sure that we have valid data on record for current discussion, but also for future studies.
And that's why we provided not only our store information, but our hiring data, our wage data by stores.
We want to get it all out there, for better or worse, so that we know what the real story is.
We might take a few hits with it, we might not, but at least it's a starting point so that we know where we need to improve and others know where we're strong and where we have opportunity.
I'm sure you saw the story in today's New York Times about the `war room' that Wal-Mart has set up there in Bentonville to get quick response out to the criticisms.
Is it a political campaign, that sort of thing?
It must cost a lot of money, for one thing.
Well, this room that you saw in The Times this morning is just a few feet from my office, so I'm very familiar with it.

And when you look at the opposition, the folks who are running the ads against Wal-Mart and out there, you know, agitating--and there's lots and lots of them who are making a living based on criticizing Wal-Mart.
They come from a campaign background.
They're approaching it like a campaign.
And we felt that we needed to do the same thing.
Our associates want us to get our story out.

Our customers want us to get, you know, the real facts, the true story out, and so we've realized that we've got to be a little more sophisticated in how we do that, and that's what we're trying to do.
We wanted to thank you for joining us today.
We've got about 30 seconds.
Is there one particular thing that you were anxious about, you wanted to correct?

No, just to keep in mind that Wal-Mart does make life better for so many people in this country, and as you look at things that you guys called `reputation hits,' the health-care memo, the reputation memo, this economic impact study--these are all ways that we're trying to get better, because you have to know where you are to know how to get to where you want to be.
And while we do a lot of things right, we're still working on getting better all the time.
Mona Williams, thank you very much.

Today we're talking about a new public image for Wal-Mart.
And joining us here in Studio 3A is Eric Dezenhall.
He's president of Dezenhall Resources, a crisis management firm here in Washington, DC.
Thanks very much for coming in.
Thanks for having me.
Now you help companies facing controversies, crises.
Is Wal-Mart's strategy to launch a pretty big PR campaign to burnish its image--is that conventional?
Is it the right way to go?
I think that it is unconventional in the traditional sense, but I think it's a very good idea given what's going on.
It's important to take a look diagnostically at exactly what type of attack this is.
This isn't just a PR campaign.

This is what's known as a corporate campaign by critics of Wal-Mart, primarily unions, designed to harass the company, and harassment is ultimately designed to bring Wal-Mart to the table from the negotiating perspective.
So this is a specific type of pathology.
So when we call it a PR campaign, to respond to it, even though in layman's terms that's the right term, I think it's very important to look at the specific strain of attack that they're facing.
So from the company's perspective, this is not this watchdog group and that activist committee; this looks concerted to them.
Absolutely.

I mean, there's no medical analogy, but if you were to use a CAT scan and look at this situation, this would register as a very specific type of problem where you have motivated adversaries who only gain by attacking you.
These are not audiences that are interested in being educated.
They don't want to learn anything.
They don't want information.
They want to attack the company.
Well, then, is public relations, which is a form of educating the public, I suppose--is that the right approach?
It's one approach.
I mean, usually these campaigns are a mixed bag.
What you see happening here--I mean, based on public reports, that is--is a political approach.
In conventional public relations, you seek to educate or advertise.
You seek to make the company--people feel good about the company.
Mm-hmm.
In unconventional warfare, which is what this is, you're not only trying to get people to like the company, you're getting them--you want them to dislike your attacker.
And that's a very different model than conventional marketing, which is why you see sort of a political war-room setup.
Wal-Mart will not win this by getting people just to love them by running advertisements with little girls with daisies in their hair.
They will have to manage this by recognizing that part of the battle is not making themselves look good, but making the other guys look bad.
In political campaign terms, drive up your opponents' negatives.
That's exactly right.
And corporations are very lily-livered by nature about admitting to wanting to do something like that.

One of the things that I thought from my perspective was admirable about what Wal-Mart is doing is most companies live in mortal terror of their critics, and they live in even worse terror of doing anything to combat their critics.
You don't see Wal-Mart denying that they are engaging in a very assertive program, in part to discredit their critics.
You saw somewhat similar tactics, I think, from McDonald's a few years ago, under assault by, among others, PETA, the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.
And Wal-Mart reformed the way it purchased meat.
It reformed the way meat is processed in this country.
Well, there's no question that attacks on companies can alter policy, and that's one of the reasons why some attack groups do it.
I mean, not every attack is immoral.
I mean, the fact is, is that every attack on the business interest is always wrapped up in a mantle of virtue.
The whole idea is, `We're doing this for the good of the people.
The fact is, is sometimes that's true; sometimes it's not.
Any attack on a company is moral, but anytime a company begins to defend itself, it's seen as immoral somehow.
Yes, policy changes are made, but it's really the obligation of the company to defend itself.
And the whole idea that anytime a company assertively defends itself, that that is some sort of ethical violation, is a concept that I reject.
